intro: Conyza copiapina, commonly known as the Copiapó ironweed, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Chile. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble daisies. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, adapting to harsh conditions with its hairy foliage and deep root system. It produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring. Conyza copiapina is often found in coastal areas and can thrive in saline soils, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
